title: Pair from Brighton facing charges in string of handicap placard thefts
author: Heather Alterisio
bullets: Two Brighton residents arrested for a series of handicap placard thefts in Allston-Brighton.
Andrea Doucette-Keating and Zachary Shelton charged with various property-related offenses.
Police recovered stolen placards, cocaine, and a BB gun at Shelton's residence.

title: Why did the Patriots abandon the run against the Raiders? Mike Vrabel explains.
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Patriots shifted to 46 passing attempts in a rainy loss to the Raiders, sidelining their ground game.
Running backs TreVeyon Henderson, Rhamondre Stevenson, and Antonio Gibson combined for 60 yards on 18 carries.
Mike Vrabel emphasized the need for improvement in both offensive line blocking and running game efficiency.

title: The T’s ‘fare engagement representatives’ are hitting the streets today. Here’s what to expect.
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: MBTA fare engagement representatives begin checks on September 8, focusing on fare evaders at subway stations.
Offenders face a written warning for a first offense, with fines ranging from $50 to $150 for repeat violations.
Massachusetts decriminalized fare evasion, but the MBTA initiates checks to address financial impacts on transit services.

title: Kendrick Bourne reportedly agrees to one-year contract with 49ers
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Kendrick Bourne signs a one-year contract with the 49ers worth up to $5 million.
Bourne was released by the Patriots in August to seek more playing time elsewhere.
Bourne returns to the 49ers, where he began his NFL career in 2017 as an undrafted free agent.

title: The Ocean Club restaurant opens in Martha’s Vineyard landmark bank building
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: The Ocean Club restaurant opened on August 27 in Martha's Vineyard's historic landmark bank at 75 Main St.
Chef Marc Orfaly leads the restaurant with a menu focused on seafood and pasta, highlighting local ingredients.
The former bank building retains original features; the vault is now a wine cellar with a communal dining space.

title: Saving pamphlets, receipts, and wrappers: Young people take on junk journaling
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Junk journaling, a trend among young people, involves using found items like pamphlets and receipts to create personalized collages.
Lauren Clark's business, Found and Flowered, offers junk journaling materials and workshops, supporting the craft's popularity in Greater Boston.
The practice appeals for its offline, hands-on nature, providing a creative outlet and community interaction across diverse age groups.

title: Review & setlist: My Chemical Romance skewers fascism at Fenway Park
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: My Chemical Romance's Fenway Park performance explored authoritarian themes, evoking Nazi and Soviet imagery through theatrical elements.
Audience participation included deciding the fate of fictional prisoners, using signs distributed at the gates to vote.
The concert featured two sets, including their album 'The Black Parade' and finished with songs outside the album.

title: After serial shoplifters swipe $18K in sunglasses at Faneuil Hall store, police issue request for tips
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Serial shoplifters stole approximately $18,000 worth of sunglasses from the Sunglass Hut at Faneuil Hall over seven incidents.
Boston Police urge the public to provide tips on the suspects involved in the heists between June and August 2025.
Boston retailers express concerns about increasing shoplifting as incidents reportedly rose 15% compared to last year.

title: Boy, 14, shot in Brockton
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: A 14-year-old boy was shot Sunday evening in Brockton, near Francis Street and Manners Avenue.
The victim was transported to a local hospital with nonlife-threatening injuries after the incident.
A silver vehicle was seen fleeing the scene, and police are continuing their investigation.

title: Feds arrest 171 suspected members of drug cartel in New England, including 49 in Mass.
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: DEA arrests 171 suspected Sinaloa Cartel members in New England, including 49 in Massachusetts, during August 2025 operations.
In New England, authorities seized 244 kg of drugs, 22,115 counterfeit pills, $1.3 million in cash, and 33 guns.
The Sinaloa Cartel is designated by the State Department as a terrorist organization and poses a significant threat.
